Blog.post: Looking for the Governing Dynamics of Engineering.... This is what i ever want to look through. My interest has always been in DSP for embedded systems....the one i want to proceed with my continual education.

MY FAVORITE QUOTES ! People see things and say 'why', but I dream things that never were and say 'why not'. - G B Shaw It's strange how much you've got to know before you know how little you know. - Anon. The finger pointing at the moon is not the moon ! - Seanny Time is precious, but truth is more precious than time. - Benjamin Disraeli There are some people who live in a dream world, and there are some who face reality; and then there are those who turn one into the other. - Douglas Everett In this world there is always danger for those who are afraid of it. - G B Shaw Imagination is the beginning of creation. You imagine what you desire; you will what you imagine; and at last you create what you will. - G B Shaw A life spent making mistakes is not only more honorable, but more useful than a life spent doing nothing. - G B Shaw One who has lost confidence can lose nothing more. - Boiste When you reach for the stars, you may not quite get one, but you won't come up with a handful of mud either. - Leo Burnett Dream as if you'll live forever. Live as if you'll die tomorrow. - James Dean Improvement makes straight roads, but the crooked roads without improvement, are the roads of Genius. - William Blake QUOTES ON THE LIGHTER SIDE ! God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, the courage to change the things I can, and the wisdom to properly dispose of the bodies of those who truly annoy me.!! AN EXCELLENT QUOTE VERY RELEVANT TO ANYONE STUDYING IN COLLEGE/SCHOOL "But you go to a great school, not for knowledge so much as for arts and habits; for the habit of attention, for the art of expression, for the art of assuming at a moment's notice a new intellectual posture, for the art of entering quickly into another person's thoughts, for the habit of submitting to censure and refutation, for the art of indicating assent or dissent in graduated terms, for the habit of regarding minute points of accuracy, for the habit of working out what is possible in a given time, for taste, for discrimination, for mental courage and mental soberness." - William Johnson Cory (1861)

Great quotes to inspire, empower and motivate you to live the life of your dreams and become the person you've always wanted to be! I f ever we hear a case of lying, we must look for a severe parents. A lie would have no sense unless the truth were felt as dangerous. ~ urlLink Alfred Alder ~ T hat in the beginning when the world was young there were a great many thoughts but no such thing as truth. Man made the truths himself and each truth was a composite of a great many vague thoughts. All about in the world were truths and they were all beautiful. ~ urlLink Sherwood Anderson ~ O ne universe made up all that is; and one God in it all, and one principle of being, and one law, the reason shared by all thinking creatures, and one truth. ~ urlLink Marcus Aurelius ~ E rror always addresses the passions and prejudices; truth scorns such mean intrigue, and only addresses the understanding and the conscience. ~ urlLink Azel Backus ~ I t is a pleasure to stand upon the shore, and to see ships tost upon the sea: a pleasure to stand in the window of a castle, and to see a battle and the adventures thereof below: but no pleasure is comparable to standing upon the vantage ground of truth... and to see the errors, and wanderings, and mists, and tempests, in the vale below. ~ urlLink Francis Bacon ~ Y ou never find yourself until you face the truth. ~ urlLink Pearl Bailey ~ I t is unfortunate, considering that enthusiasm moves the world, that so few enthusiasts can be trusted to speak the truth. ~ urlLink Arthur James Balfour ~ T here's a little truth in all jive, and a little jive in all truth. ~ urlLink Leonard Barnes ~ N othing is poorer than a truth expressed as it was thought. Committed to writing in such cases, it is not even a bad photograph. Truth wants to be startled abruptly, at one stroke, from her self-immersion, whether by uproar, music or cries for help. ~ urlLink Walter Benjamin ~ B etween truth and the search for it, I choose the second. ~ urlLink Bernard Berenson ~ T here is an element of truth in every idea that lasts long enough to be called corny. ~ urlLink Irving Berlin ~ S eek and you will find. ~ urlLink Bible ~ I will tell you the truth as soon as I figure it out. ~ urlLink Wayne Birmingham ~ W hen you want to fool the world, tell the truth. ~ urlLink Otto Von Bismarck ~ F or everything exists and not one sigh nor smile nor tear, one hair nor particle of dust, not one can pass away. ~ urlLink William Blake ~ T ruth can never be told so as to be understood, and not be believed. ~ urlLink William Blake ~ T he great seal of truth is simplicity. ~ urlLink Herman Boerhaave ~ T ruth lies within ourselves: it takes no rise from outward things, whatever you may believe. There is an inmost center in us all, where truth abides in fullness and to Know rather consists in opening out a way whence the imprisoned splendor may escape than in effecting entry for light supposed to be without. ~ urlLink Robert Browning ~ T here is no such source of error as the pursuit of truth. ~ urlLink Samuel Butler ~ A few observation and much reasoning lead to error; many observations and a little reasoning to truth. ~ urlLink Alexis Carrel ~ Y ou can only find truth with logic if you have already found truth without it. ~ urlLink Gilbert K. Chesterton ~ T he pursuit of truth will set you free; even if you never catch up with it. ~ urlLink Clarence Darrow ~ Y ou never see what you want to see, forever playing to the gallery. ~ urlLink Robertson Davies ~ T ime is precious, but truth is more precious than time. ~ urlLink Benjamin Disraeli ~ O nly the hand that erases can write the true thing. ~ urlLink Meister Eckhart ~ A ll these constructions and the laws connecting them can be arrived at by the principle of looking for the mathematically simplest concepts and the link between them. ~ urlLink Albert Einstein ~ W hoever undertakes to set himself up as judge in the field of truth and knowledge is shipwrecked by the laughter of the Gods. ~ urlLink Albert Einstein ~ T he greater the truth the greater the libel. ~ urlLink Lord Ellenborough ~ T ruth is beautiful, without doubt; but so are lies. ~ urlLink Ralph Waldo Emerson ~ W hatever separates you from the Truth, throw it away, it will vanish anyhow.- ~ urlLink Yumus Emre ~ A man that seeks truth and loves it must be reckoned precious to any human society. ~ urlLink Epictetus ~ I f I had my hand full of truth, I would take good care how I opened it. ~ urlLink Bernard Le Bovier Fontenelle ~ T he truth is always the strongest argument. ~ urlLink Sophocles ~ T ruth is a thing immortal and perpetual, and it gives to us a beauty that fades not away in time. ~ urlLink Max Fuller ~ W henever you have truth it must be given with love, or the message and the messenger will be rejected. ~ urlLink Mahatma Gandhi ~ S ay not, "I have found the truth," but rather, "I have found a truth. ~ urlLink Kahlil Gibran ~ I don't want yes men around me. I want everyone to tell the truth, even if it costs them their jobs. ~ urlLink Samuel Goldwyn ~ W hat is, is; and what ain't, ain't ~ urlLink Joseph E. Granville ~ T ruth is not determined by majority vote. ~ urlLink Doug Gwyn ~ E ffective thinking consists of being able to arrive at the truth; truth being defined as that which exists. ~ urlLink Calvin S. Hall ~ T he dissident does not operate in the realm of genuine power at all. He is not seeking power. He has no desire for office and does not gather votes. He does not attempt to charm the public, he offers nothing and promises nothing. He can offer, if anything, only his own skin -- and he offers it solely because he has no other way of affirming the truth he stands for. His actions simply articulate his dignity as a citizen, regardless of the cost. ~ urlLink Vaclav Havel ~ I 'm going to speak my mind because I have nothing to lose. ~ urlLink S. I. They're all true. ~ urlLink Ernest Hemingway ~ R espect for the truth comes close to being the basis for all morality. ~ urlLink Frank Herbert ~ A ll great truths are simple in final analysis, and easily understood; if they are not, they are not great truths. ~ urlLink Napoleon Hill ~ T ruth, when not sought after, rarely comes to light. ~ urlLink Oliver Wendell Holmes ~ L earn to see things as they really are, not as we imagine they are. ~ urlLink Vernon Howard ~ T he wise boldly pick up a truth as soon as they hear it. Don't wait or a moment, or you'll lose your head. ~ urlLink Hsueh-Dou ~ W e should face reality and our past mistakes in an honest, adult way. Huxley ~ T he man who fears no truth has nothing to fear from lies. ~ urlLink Thomas Jefferson ~ W hat the imagination seizes as beauty must be the truth. ~ urlLink John Keats ~ N o matter what you believe, it doesn't change the facts. ~ urlLink Al Kersha ~ R eceiving a new truth is like adding a new sense. ~ urlLink Liebig ~ T ruth, after all, wears a different face to everybody, and it would be too tedious to wait till all were agreed. ~ urlLink James Russell Lowell ~ P eace if possible, but truth at any rate. ~ urlLink Martin Luther ~ A lways tell the truth -- it's the easiest thing to remember. ~ urlLink David Mamet ~ I believe that it is better to tell the truth than a lie. I believe it is better to be free than to be a slave. And I believe it is better to know than to be ignorant. ~ urlLink H. L. Mencken ~ W e spend all our time looking for some concept of Truth, but Truth is what is left when we drop all concepts. ~ urlLink David Merzel ~ T ruth is not beautiful, neither is ugly, Why should it be either? Truth is Truth. ~ urlLink Owen C. Middleton ~ N o problem can be solved until it is reduced to some simple form. The changing of a vague difficulty into a specific, concrete form is a very essential element in thinking. ~ urlLink John Pierpont Morgan ~ T ruth and virtue conquer. ~ urlLink Motto ~ T he more abstract the truth you want to teach, the more thoroughly you must seduce the senses to accept it. ~ urlLink Friedrich Nietzsche ~ T ruth is a thing immortal and perpetual, and it gives to us a beauty that fades not away in time. ~ urlLink Frank Norris ~ T elling someone the truth is a loving act. ~ urlLink Mal Pancoast ~ I pray without ceasing now. My personal prayer is: Make me an instrument which only truth can speak. ~ urlLink Peace Pilgrim ~ N ot every truth is the better for showing its face undisguised; and often silence is the wisest thing for a man to heed. ~ urlLink Pindar ~ T he solutions all are simple -- after you have arrived at them. But they're simple only when you know already what they are. ~ urlLink Robert M. Pirsig ~ T hey deem him their worst enemy who tells them the truth. ~ urlLink Plato ~ A bare assertion is not necessarily the naked truth. ~ urlLink George D. Prentice ~ T ruth fears nothing but concealment. ~ urlLink Proverb ~ A half truth is a whole lie. ~ urlLink Yiddish Proverb ~ T he truth only irritates those it enlightens, but does not convert. ~ urlLink Pasquier Quesnel ~ Y ou'll never get mixed up if you simply tell the truth. Then you don't have to remember what you have said, and you never forget what you have said. ~ urlLink Sam Rayburn ~ T ruth can be a dangerous thing. It is quite patient and relentless. ~ urlLink R. Scott Richards ~ I f you ever injected truth into politics you would have no politics. ~ urlLink Will Rogers ~ T here is no power on earth more formidable than the truth. ~ urlLink Margaret Lee Runbeck ~ T he fact that an opinion has been widely held is no evidence whatever that it is not utterly absurd. ~ urlLink Utterly Russell ~ N othing is true. Everything is permitted. ~ urlLink Sabbah ~ T he basic truth of all things, as nearly as we may ever dream of determining and knowing this truth, is form, that which is, as it is. Smith ~ E verything you add to the truth subtracts from the truth. ~ urlLink Alexander Solzhenitsyn ~ P eople deserve... the truth. They deserve honesty.
